Description: David Kirkaldy's Testing & Experimenting Works at 99 Southwark Street set the first international standards in materials testing; a science that has wide-reaching effects on everyday life today. Today, this unique Victorian workshop keeps alive our direct link with Kirkaldy's innovation, at the heart of this bustling commercial district of London. Kirkaldy's Testing Works preserves Kirkaldy's unique Universal Testing Machine - the huge hydraulic powered machine he designed and had built in Leeds - in full working order in the premises he built to house it. As well as presenting the story of the family who ran the business for almost 100 years and of the wider development of materials testing, the workshop and the Universal Testing Machine provide a unique crucible for new experimentation and collaboration - which can inspire future generations of scientists and artists alike to continue enquiring into the properties of the materials on which we build our lives. Your tour will include a 1-hour 30-minute tour around the Works (see the ticket options for the time slots available), including an introductory video and demonstrations of some of the smaller machines in our collection. We're now opening for timed entry (1-hour 30-minute tours with a maximum number of 10 visitors) through Eventbrite and are not accepting admissions at the door. Please arrive on time for your slot as we will not be able to admit you to a later timed entry. Make sure you've selected the right time slot when you buy your tickets. At this time, we are not offering Concessions tickets or refunds due to problems with our financial security caused by the lockdown. We hope that you understand our position as a small museum fully reliant on ticket sales. We're also now opening on some weekday evenings for shorter tours of the Museum. More info here. Even in these strange times, we hope you'll join us in celebrating the vision of a forgotten hero of engineering science. Find out more on our website here. Images: ¬©Peter Dazeley
Title: Tour Kirkaldy's Testing Works
Subtitle: Join us at Kirkaldy's Testing Works to tour David Kirkaldy's world-famous Testing & Experimenting Works.

Description: The Beading Workshop includes joint sessions where I share my knowledge of creating bespoke pieces of jewellery. We will work with new modern styles, create from our own imaginations and also recreate Ancestral styles that harness the natural healing energies of crystals. As a result we will also become aware of what crystals are best to be used for any particular desire including balancing our own personal energy fields and even helping to maintain healthy blood which is good for those who suffer from conditions such as Sickle Cell and others similar in nature. At the end of each session each person will leave with a new piece of jewellery hand crafted by themselves and a bit more knowledgeable on the traditions of old. 'In the past years I have worked with Sickle Cell Cause in such areas as Sponsored Walks,						  Manning an Awareness Post at The North Middlesex Hospital,														 Fundraising and Spreading Awareness at The Notting Hill Carnival and on Public Transportation via leafleting, Visiting Parliament to discuss the importance of Sickle Cell Treatment in the U.K with M.Ps.		 Attending discussions with Palliative care stressing the importance of The George Marsh Centre to the Sickle Cell Community when under threat of losing it,  Supporting the group‚Äôs budget with personal donations of 10% of my business sales, and generally supporting those sufferers that I have come into contact with, with encouragement and any knowledge I have of aides/ contacts/remedies that may be of benefit to their individual needs. I have found this work (although hard to swallow when faced with such pain and suffering that one feels helpless to wipe away from their lives completely) Most satisfying when the results of our work bring about a real positive difference in people‚Äôs lives, unity amongst us and smiles to their faces'.  Blair x
Organizer: Sickle Cell C.A.U.S.E - Community Peer To Peer Support Group

Description: Turkish Coffee Class Join us for a delightful Turkish Coffee Class, where you'll discover the art and tradition of brewing authentic Turkish coffee. This in-person event will take place at the  a cup of coffee London Workshop. Immerse yourself in the rich flavors and cultural heritage of this beloved beverage. During the class, you will be guided through the entire process, from talking about the coffee beans used for Turkish Coffee to brewing the perfect cup. You'll learn about the unique brewing Turkish Coffee techniques and the significance of coffee in Turkish culture. Get ready to savor the rich aroma and taste of this centuries-old tradition. Whether you're a coffee enthusiast or simply curious about Turkish culture, this event is perfect for you. Come and enjoy a fun-filled afternoon of learning, socializing, and of course, indulging in delicious Turkish coffee. Don't miss out on this unique opportunity to expand your coffee knowledge and experience a taste of Turkiye in the heart of London! In this 2hr session, The class will cover Taste the first form of coffee  beverage same as it was discovered 570 years ago in Yemen History of Turkish coffee How to brew Traditional Turkish Coffee Hands on cooking Turkish Coffee with "cezve" (traditional coffee-making pot). How to prepare a traditional Turkish Coffee time Find out the best accompaniments to Turkish Coffee  Taste and learn different variations of Turkish Coffees such as Cilveli, Cardamom, Tatar, etc. What's included As much Turkish Coffee as you can drink during the class Complementary Turkish Coffee in metal box to take home. E-Turkish Coffee recipes (you will be sent a link to load  after the class). Small sweet bites and nuts will be served during the class to complement the Turkish Coffee time. Please let us know if you have any nut allergies before the class. Turkish Coffee is a vegan drink. The event can be booked for close groups for birthday purposes. You can bring your cake and candles. There are plenty of cutleries and plates to serve here. The cake can be served at the coffee time part. We require a minimum of 3 participants to run this class and reserve the right to cancel it due to insufficient enrolment. If this occurs, you will have a full refund.  We only process refunds if notified 7 days before the class takes place. Eventbrite's fee is nonrefundable.
Title: Turkish Coffee Class
Subtitle: A hands-on, in-person Turkish Coffee Class. Learn all about Turkish Coffee, tips and technics at a relaxed workshop.

Description: Join us for fun relaxed workshops that are free from judgment and are suitable for all abilities. This is a safe space to create and connect with queer people. In these guided workshops, you'll be offered support, tips, advice and practical demonstrations. We will hand-paint candles with interesting colourful designs, motifs, and patterns. At the end of the session, you will have two beautiful candles to take home, to keep or to gift to others. Please note: all materials such as candles, paint, brushes, and paper are included in the price for this session. In this workshop, we'll create our own tarot cards. We will look at a classic tarot deck and take inspiration from the cards that we connect to the most.We'll then design and create our own tarot cards which can be graphic, abstract, figurative, monotone, or colourful. There is no right or wrong way, you are just gently encouraged to be expressive and go with your feelings!Please note: all materials such as tarot decks, card, paper, paint, brushes, and pens are included in the price for this session. Join Queer Art Club for a Cat-Mask making workshop. We will look at the power of the cat, their role throughout history, symbolism, and mysticism. We will then create our very own cat mask to celebrate the fuzzy felines. At the end of the session you will have your very own hand painted, and decorated cat mask to take home. Please note: All materials such as cat mask, paint, brushes, gemstones, feathers, and card are included in the ticket price. About the facilitator: Queer Art Club is facilitated by Paul Madley, a queer artist and creative based in London. Accessibility: The Centre's accessibility statement is here. Covid and mpox safety at the London LGBTQ+ Community Centre: To keep our community safe, we ask that all visitors do not visit the Centre if they are feeling unwell including headache, fever, sore throat, consistent cough, chills and unusual spots, scabs or ulcers. You can wear a mask if you feel more comfortable. We also have masks and hand sanitiser available at the Centre. For current information on Covid-19 and mpox please visit the NHS website.
Title: Queer Art Club
Subtitle: Monthly Queer Art Club workshops that connect Queer people through art and creativity.

Description: The Beatles are often referred to as a Liverpool band. Of course they started there, but as soon as they started recording they moved to London and from February 1963 did all of their recording, living and loving there. As Ringo says in Anthology "If you are in our business, you go to London- that's where it happens". So there are many places (if you know where to look) which allow you to trace key moments in their careers and lives: this walk takes you around the most important, many of which you may not be aware of. And it covers the more famous ones, like the Apple rooftop (as featured in Peter Jackson's recent "Get Back" film) and the zebra crossing outside EMI studios in Abbey Road. Note: walk includes (optional) tube journey at end to Abbey Road, not included in the Price: if you don't want to visit this, walk ends in Baker St)
Title: The Beatles: Abbey Road plus
Subtitle: Explore where The Beatles lived, worked and socialised in London through virtually the whole of their recording career

Description: Join me for a one on one Akashic Records consultation and a transformative experience.  If you prefer an online consultation please click here. The Akashic Records are the deepest soul level information about us (and everything in existence).  You may access your records to: Most people access their Akashic Records so they can live to their fullest potential and in relation to others - personal life, career/business, relationships, financial, family, health etc.  We eliminate all guess work and remove all doubt.  Once booked, you will receive a preparation email.  You can choose to have your session audio recorded and this will be sent to you after the consultation for ongoing personal growth and healing work.  I am so looking forward to holding space for you to access your Akashic Records. Everyone is welcome and no prior experience is necessary; so join me if you feel drawn to this or you're just curious. "It has been such a positive and revealing adventure. It was a first time for me and I surprised myself as to how easily I embraced the suggestions and carried them along into my day-to-day living since!" - Claude-m F "Thank you for this truly transformational session. Loved it!" - Maya M "This is such a gentle and powerful way to move forward in your life and I would highly recommend these sessions to feel a great sense of knowing and peace. Thank you so much!" - I Gordon Maggie Sarfo is a Personal Growth Mentor and Akashic Records Consultant; for individuals, entrepreneurs and leaders looking to access their highest potential. She spent 15+ years in a successful corporate career where she came across people who are faced with blocks that prevent them from living to their fullest potential.  Then in 2016, she woke up one morning with the sound of Akasha ringing in her ears. This led her to discover the Akashic Records as a tool to unlock these blocks and support herself and others, so they can move forward in confidence. She is certified and specialises in personal and business Akashic Records.  Maggie combines holistic modalities (including DNA healing tools) with her business and people development abilities to balance all 4 aspects of us ‚Äì physical, mental, emotional and spiritual. Based in the UK, she serves local and global clients in person or remotely online.
Title: One on One Akashic Records Consultation - London
Subtitle: An Akashic Records consultation allows you to address issues, experience love, peace, non-judgemement and move forward in confidence.

Description: New Scientist presents ... We are on the cusp of a revolution in genetics. The cost of sequencing a genome has tumbled, DNA testing has become routine and new technologies such as CRISPR are allowing us to edit the code of life like never before. But the genetics revolution is only just getting started. Join six leading experts who will be your guide to the rapidly evolving field of genetics. Since the time of Watson and Crick we‚Äôve learned so much about our genetic code ‚Äì from reading which genes code for certain proteins to writing our own DNA code to create new microorganisms. NEW EVENT FORMAT FOR 2024 We are always seeking ways to make our events more inclusive and to find new ways to deliver value to you. For 2024 we have reduced the ticket prices and introduced a new ticket option ‚Äúsuper early bird‚Äù for our Instant Expert events. All our Instant Expert events will be held at Conway Hall, 25 Red Lion Square, London. An Instant Expert ticket will no longer included refreshments or lunch, but the agenda includes a lunch break and there are many great eateries close to Conway Hall to choose from. But what doesn‚Äôt change is that each event will continue to feature six expert speakers sharing their knowledge and latest research on the event topic. We hope you like the changes we have made to the event format for 2024, and as always we welcome your feedback. At this Instant Expert, you‚Äôll learn about: Talks and speakers: The Human Cell Atlas: Harnessing the Single Cell Biology Revolution Kerstin Meyer, Principal Staff Scientist, Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute The human body is made up of approximately 37 trillion cells, which belong to different cell types that together form our organs. The Human Cell Atlas is an international consortium aiming to identify all these cell types, understand how they function in health, and find out how they become abnormal in disease. With the help of single cell biology, particularly single cell RNA sequencing, we can now study millions of cells simultaneously and use computational tools like machine learning to analyze the data we gather. By combining this extensive knowledge with spatial information, our goal is to create a comprehensive "google maps" of the human body. I will describe our work in identifying new cell types and states, as well as uncovering tissue structures that support organ function. In the future, we hope to utilise this knowledge to engineer "designer cells" and develop new approaches to treat disease. Epigenetics ‚Äì Why DNA Is Not Your Destiny Nessa Carey, British biologist, Visiting Professor, Imperial College London DNA ‚Äì it‚Äôs important, but in all except the simplest organisms it‚Äôs nowhere near sufficient as an explanation of biology. How can it be, when two genetically identical ‚Äúthings‚Äù can be so different from one another? Something else is at play, and that something is another layer of information called epigenetics. If you‚Äôve ever been curious about why identical twins aren‚Äôt indistinguishable, or why the cells in our skin and kidneys are so different even though they use the same DNA code, or even why Californian condors can display virgin birth but humans can‚Äôt, epigenetics is the topic for you. Weeds: Nature‚Äôs ultimate survivors Dana MacGregor, Plant Molecular Geneticist, Rothamsted Research Even though weeds are arguably the most impactful group of plants, directly reducing crop yields and increase farming expenses, our knowledge about them lags far behind that of crops they affect. Weeds have been shaped by distinct natural and human-driven selection and they evolved have a suite of exceptional traits in response to and to circumvent those pressures. To explore 'weedy' traits, we're bringing these troublesome plants into the molecular laboratory and generating a molecular-level understanding of how they help weeds survive. Exciting breakthroughs, such as methods to temporarily control gene expression guided by fully sequenced and annotated genomes, have already been achieved. Join us for this presentation as we discuss these breakthroughs and explore how understanding the genetic and molecular aspects of agricultural weeds gained in the lab is crucial for developing effective and innovative solutions for tomorrow‚Äôs agriculture. New genetic findings from old bones Marina Silva, Postdoctoral Fellow, The Francis Crick Institute How can the remnants of ancient bodies help us decode the mysteries of our past? Join Dr Marina Silva, a Postdoctoral Fellow at The Francis Crick Institute, to discover how we are able to extract and decode ancient DNA in archaeological bone fragments. She will guide us through the cutting-edge techniques employed at the intersection of genomics, archaeology, and anthropology that uncover the untold stories of individuals who lived thousands of years ago. Francis Galton, eugenics and why we need new science stories Subhadra Das, Author, historian, broadcaster, and comedian Francis Galton is the most influential Victorian scientist most people have never heard of. If you have heard of him, you may know that his research fed into a wide range of sciences from meteorology to criminology, psychology, sociology and statistics. Through his work in mathematical biology in the last decades of the nineteenth century, Galton is widely held to be one of the godfathers of modern genetics. In 1883 Galton coined the word ‚Äòeugenics‚Äô to describe his vision for a society governed by scientific knowledge. In this talk, Subhadra Das, former curator of the Galton Collection at UCL, will describe the colonial and racist ideas that framed Galton‚Äôs work, and explain why, for her, the absence of Galton‚Äôs story in our popular science history discourse is a story in itself. Recent Advances in Genetic Manipulation ‚Äì from the bench to bedside Antony Adamson, Senior Experimental Officer, University of Manchester How does CRISPR-Cas9 work? Why has it become the tool of choice for genetic manipulation? And how is it used on a daily basis? Join Antony Adamson from the University of Manchester as he explains the science behind this Nobel Prize-winning technique. Antony will also explore the future of gene editing, highlighting exciting developments in the clinical use of this technology to treat genetic disease, but also the drawbacks and ethical challenges that need to be addressed. Who should attend? Anyone interested in genetics, whatever your age or background. Whether you're a scientist, a student or simply a fascinated human being, Instant Expert: The Genetics Revolution offers the chance to learn directly from the experts at our one-day masterclass. Benefits of attending: What's included in your ticket: Booking information:
Title: Instant Expert: The Genetics Revolution
Subtitle: A one-day masterclass for anyone interested in genetics, whatever your age or background, to learn directly from the experts.

Description: Multi Award winner Shaanti is proud to present Massi's Yard Brunch, a 90's + 00's Bhangra, Desi Beats and Bollywood-filled brunch that celebrates British South Asian music and culture. Join us as we celebrate two decades of amazing music and culture that brought us greats like Goodness Gracious Me and Bend It Like Beckham! The '90s + '00s saw the rise of Bhangra bands like Alaap, Apna Sangeet and Heera and the emergence of Panjabi MC, Jay-Z's hit single 'Beware of the Boys' as well as Malkit Singh and Stereo Nation. It was a time when the mainstream was dominated by British South Asian culture and a time when many of the biggest names in hip-hop and bhangra were coming together in perfect harmony. Legends like Truth Hurts, Raki, Erick Sermon, Redman, and Kanye West were embracing Bollywood while home-grown stars like RDB, Dr Zeus, B21, Tigerstyle, Juttla, Surinder Rattan, Metz and Trix were releasing iconic anthems of time. Bally Sagoo, Cornershop, Apache Indian and The Rishi Rich Project featuring Jay Sean and Juggy D dominated the UK charts and Wolverhampton-born Jas Mann‚Äôs ‚ÄòSpaceman‚Äô hit the number one spot in the UK Singles Chart. The 90s also saw the rise of The Asian Underground movement; Talvin Singh, Joi, Nitin Sawhney, State of Bengal, M.I.A, UK Apache, Basmarsh and Shri were making waves and pushing out boundaries in music. Madonna donned Henna, Gwen Stefani rocked a bindi and East is East introduced us to a new catchphrase: 'You bloody basta¬£%!!!!' Massi's Yard Brunch will take you back to the 90s and early 2000s with a mix of classic Bollywood, Bhangra, Desi Beats, RNB and Hip Hop tunes. Enjoy complimentary Rum Punch in the first hour and dance your way through five hours of the best British Asian music from the decades. Street food will also be available from the in-house kitchen* (T&Cs apply, see below). Join us for an unforgettable experience, celebrating the incredible music of yesteryear! #MassisYardBrunch #Don'tTellMassi Just dont tell Massi! Description: Curated by artist David Blandy and writer Jamie Sutcliffe in association with Strange Attractor Press, Areas Of Effect: Planar Systems, Critical Roles, and Gaming Imaginaries is a one-day symposium on Tabletop Role Playing Games (TTRPGs) with live game sessions. Forming part of arebyte‚Äôs programme The Body, The Mind, The Soul which questions the complex nature of humanity in the realm of technological progress, the event brings together artists, game designers, theorists, and philosophers to discuss these wildly expansive forms of play in which players utilise both their imaginations and chance mechanics (such as dice rolls) to determine the actions of fictional characters and the scenarios surrounding them. The symposium explores TTRPGs as physical interfaces between the body and the imaginary, and questions their myriad uses as transformative activities. Beyond leisure activities, might we think of these strange forms of play as novel opportunities for immersivity, problem solving, explorations of contingency, and perhaps most importantly, communal storytelling? Speakers at the event include acclaimed RPG designers Emmy Allan, Kayla Dice, Mike Mason, Chris McDowall, Samuel Mui, and Zedeck Siew, alongside writers, historians and theorists such as Stu Horvath, Timothy Linward, Mark Pilkington, and Simon O‚ÄôSullivan. An exhibition of TTRPGs-inspired video games by artists Kitty Clark, Uma Breakdown, John Powell-Jones, Petra Szem√°n, and Holly White are hosted on computers and available to play for visitors throughout the whole event. The day culminates in live TTRPG play sessions of the games ECOMOFOS!! by artist David Blandy and SUPERZEROES by TTRPG game designer Samuel Mui, amongst others, inviting the audience to play with a deck of uniquely designed TTRPG playing cards. The event features a selection of merchandise and publications from Strange Attractor Press, independent London-based bookshop Igloo Tree, Massachusetts-based MIT Press and zine supplier Antipode Zines. Games from Laurie O‚ÄôConnel and Loot the Room will also be on sale. Read more about the event here. S ymposium programme: 11 - 11:15am: INTRODUCTION TO TTRPGS by David Blandy and Jamie Sutcliffe Starting off the symposium, Jamie and David welcome visitors, introduce the programme for the day and touch upon the world of TTRPGS. 11:15 - 11:45am: ON ROLEPLAYING GAMES by Simon O‚Äô Sullivan Artist and theorist Simon O'Sullivan will begin the symposium with a keynote talk considering the imaginative spaces and practices of role playing games considered as a distinct form of fictioning. 11:45am - 1pm: BETWEEN HEXCRAWLS AND BIOSPHERES with Holly White, Zedeck Siew, David Blandy (chair) Exploring the myriad functions of speculative ecology in role playing environments, addressing the creation of flora, fauna and folklore that work to colour and complicate diverse worlds of play in a time of ecological collapse. 1:40 - 3pm: FROM ODD PASTS TO GRIMDARK FUTURES with Timothy Linward, Kayla Dice, Chris McDowall (chair) From privately imagined locales to vast, communally written megatexts, this discussion will focus on the process and practice of worldbuilding, interrogating the various textures of myth and fabulation asking to what ends our novel worlds might be put. 3 - 3:25pm: MONSTERS, ALIENS, AND HOLES IN THE GROUND Stu Horvath in conversation with Jamie Sutcliffe TTRPG historian and co-host of the Vintage RPG Podcast Stu Horvath introduces his landmark new book Monsters, Aliens, and Holes In The Ground: A Guide to Tabletop Roleplaying Games From D&D To Mothership, published in 2023 by the MIT Press. 3:35 - 5pm: NAMELESS HORRORS! CREEPING FLESH! with Mike Mason, Emmy Allen, Sam Mui, Mark Pilkington Focusing on the aesthetics, politics, and arresting experiences of horror, this conversation will look to various exercises in the macabre, horrific, and supernatural to test role playing‚Äôs capacities for innovative storytelling, moral quandary, and new forms of autobiographical fiction. 5:15 - 8:30pm: LIVE TTRPG PLAY with David Blandy, Samuel Mui Following these insightful talks, have a go at playing alternative TTRPGs with friends and other visitors! The games will be facilitated by TTRPG experts and game designers. Throughout the entire symposium, a selection of TTRPG-inspired video games will be free to be play on computers in the gallery. Spanning from ecological utopias to imaginary lives, see below for the full list of games and their retrospective game designers. * ** Image credits: Illustration by Daniel Locke for David Blandy‚Äôs ECO MOFOS!! * ** Jamie Sutcliffe is a writer, curator, and co-director of Strange Attractor Press. His work explores artistic encounters with science fictive fabulation, the politics of gaming, animation and its multiple entanglements with developments in the life sciences, haunted media, the digital uncanny, and the persistence of myth, all understood as technologies of selfhood. He is the editor of Documents of Contemporary Art: Magic, published by The Whitechapel Gallery and The MIT Press, and his essays, reviews, and interviews have been featured in Art Monthly, Frieze, The White Review, Rhizome, Art Review, The Quietus, Art Agenda, Bricks From The Kiln, and IsThisIt, amongst others. @intron_depot David Blandy (1976, UK, Lives & works in Brighton) makes work that slips between performance and video, digital and analogue, investigating the stories and cultural forces that inform and influence our lives. Collaboration is central to his practice, examining communal and personal heritage and interdependence. With research spanning multiple forms of archive, from fandoms to the archive of the body, historic texts to academic libraries, archaeology and ecological theory, twitch streams and film archives, Blandy weaves poetic works that explore the complexities of the contemporary subject. @david_blandy_ Event made in partnership with Strange Attractor Press.
Title: Areas Of Effect: Planar Systems, Critical Roles, and Gaming Imaginaries
Subtitle: TTRPG designers, writers and artists address the hopes currently instilled in Tabletop Role Playing Games as a transformative activity.

Description: ACEN is excited to announce that the 2024 Parent Summit will take place on SATURDAY 9th March 9.30am - 4.30pm Wimbledon High School - (Mansel Rd, London SW19 4AB) The ACEN (African Caribbean Education Network) Parent Summit, now in its third year, will be held at Wimbledon High School, London from m to 4.30pm on Saturday9 th March 2024. This event is aimed at parents of African Caribbean children interested in finding out about applying to independent and/or grammar schools and will provide Black parents/carers and students with the opportunity to learn about and understand the admissions processes for the 7/8+, 10/11+ and 13+ entry points. Admissions guidance, advice and information on bursary and scholarship applications will be provided by representatives from a selection of schools. In addition, Black parents who currently have children in the independent and/or grammar sectors, alongside a panel of current students, will share valuable insights into their recent experiences of successfully navigating the admissions processes, the transition, and settling into their current schools. Tutors specialising in grammar and independent school exam preparation across all entry points will also be providing crucial information on all aspects of exam preparation and will be keen to answer your questions. There‚Äôs something for the children too! Students in years 4 to 6 will also have the opportunity to participate in activities and workshops on the day where they will get advice and tips directly from students in independent or grammar schools and tutors who will give them a taster of the topics and techniques that selective school exams will require them to master. We are thrilled that BookLove ( www.thisisbooklove.com) will also be joining us on the day. The BookLove Carnival is a multicultural travelling book carnival and online shop which is campaigning for classrooms and reading lists to be more inclusive. 20p from every book they sell will be donated to providing free multicultural books for schools. Refreshments and a light lunch are also included in the price. Children in year 4 and above are welcome and their attendance is free. Unfortunately, we can not cater to children below this age. Families with children on pupil premium can also register to attend for free. Note: Wimbledon High is easily accessible by public transport and there is limited on street parking Visit our website here for the full timetable
Title: ACEN Parent Summit 2024  - Accessing Independent & Grammar Schools
Subtitle: Join us in person to find out how to successfully navigate selective school admissions for Black parents and students on Saturday 9th March

Description: The eighth annual Islamic Archaeology day hosted by SOAS and UCL will be held at the UCL Institute of Archaeology on Saturday 9th March 2024, 11-6pm. The workshop presents papers on the latest archaeological research across the Islamic world and is followed by a drinks reception. **For reduced early-bird tickets, please register by Sunday February 18th 2024**. Organisers: Corisande Fenwick (UCL), Hugh Kennedy (SOAS/UCL), Veronica Occari (UCL), Scott Redford (SOAS), Viva Sacco (UCL), Paul Wordsworth (UCL) Programme Session 1 (Chair: Hugh Kennedy, SOAS/ UCL) 11:00 Welcome & Introduction (Corisande Fenwick, UCL) 11:15 Extraordinary investment: urban infrastructure and religious architecture in the desert town of Dandanakan (Turkmenistan) Martina Rugiadi (The Met, New York), Paul Wordsworth (UCL), Mukhammed Annaevich Mamedov (National Administration for the Protection, Study, and Restoration of Cultural and Historical Monuments of Turkmenistan), Rejep Jepbarov (State Historical and Cultural Park "Ancient Merv", Turkmenistan) 11:40 Christian peasants in Al-Andalus: new light on Islamization from T√≥zar (Granada, Spain) Luca Mattei (University of Granada) 12:05 Linking settlement patterns and irrigation networks in the Otrar Oasis (Kazakhstan) Katie Campbell (Cambridge), Serik Akylbek (Otrar State Archaeological Museum), Mark Macklin (Lincoln), Willem Toonen (VU Amsterdam), James Thomas (Lincoln), Davit Naskidashvili (Ghent), Karl Smith (Oxford), Ali Seraliyev (Gumilev Eurasian National University, Astana) 12:30 Archaeology & the Crusades. The Case of Kinet (Turkey) Scott Redford (SOAS) 1:00 Lunch Session 2 (Chair: Viva Sacco, UCL) 2:00 Glass in transition: the transformation of the glass economy in Sicily during the Islamic period Francesca Colangeli (University of Genoa) 2:25 The technology of polychrome glazed ceramics in Ifrƒ´qiya: new data from the Medjerda Valley (Tunisia) Veronica Occari (UCL), Heike M√∂ller (DAI Berlin), Corisande Fenwick (UCL), Patrick Quinn (UCL), Ian Freestone (UCL), Moheddine Chaouali (Institut National de Patrimoine, Tunis), Philipp von Rummel (DAI Berlin) 2:50 Used and re-used: ceramic repairs on East and Southeast Asian ceramics from Bahrain Yiying Li (University of Exeter) 3:15 Reflections on glass: the compositions, trade and possible meanings of Islamic glass bangles Charlotte Nash (University of Kent/ British Museum) 3:45 Tea break Session 3 (Chair: Scott Redford, SOAS) 4:15 Archaeobotany and agricultural change at Bardha'a (Azerbaijan) David Stone (The Discovery Programme: Centre for Archaeology and Innovation Ireland) 4:40 The Ottoman ruralscape: new data from Tell Zeyd (Iraq) Cristina Tonghini (Ca' Foscari University), Jacopo Boschini (Ca' Foscari University), Rita Dal Martello (Ca' Foscari University), Onur Usta (√áanakkale University) 5:05 The last of the Persian Gulf‚Äôs sewn boats: recording the survivors of an ancient nautical technology John P Cooper (University of Exeter), Alessandro Ghidoni (University of Exeter), Shadi Kalantar (University of Naples ‚Äòl‚ÄôOrientale‚Äô) and Chiara Zazzaro (University of Naples ‚Äòl‚ÄôOrientale‚Äô). 5:30 From Ottoman laws to illustrated periodicals: Ottoman responses to the neglect, looting and preservation of Islamic antiquities (Ozan Huseyin, SOAS) 6-7pm Reception 7 :15pm Dinner (for those who have pre-booked). For more information on the Islamic Archaeology Network and its events: http://www.ucl.ac.uk/archaeology/research/directory/islamic-archaeology-network
Title: Islamic Archaeology Day 2024
Subtitle: The 8th annual Islamic Archaeology day hosted by SOAS and UCL will be held in at the UCL Institute of Archaeology on Saturday 9th March

Description: Join us for the next Dazed x MUBI Cinema Club screening ‚Äì a UK premiere of the documentary The Last Year of Darkness, which offers an unfiltered and authentic glimpse of queer youth in Chengdu, directed by Benjamin Mullinkosson. The event will include Q&A with the director himself in partnership with HOWL Worldwide, as well as an afterparty with DJ sets from Cosmic Caz and Nanzhen Yang. Titled The Last Year of Darkness, the film offers a portrait of life in the city ‚Äì often regarded as a safe oasis for queer Chinese youth ‚Äì as it undergoes cultural and economic changes that threaten the existence of its underground spaces. At the centre of this story is Funky Town, an underground club that represents a ‚Äúhaven for outsiders who live every weekend like it‚Äôs their last‚Äù, which is on the brink of closure due to the expansion of the city‚Äôs subway. Mullinkosson‚Äôs bass-heavy document of this condemned club scene follows young, queer clubbers, DJs, and performance artists through the drudgery and worries of their daytime lives, which are contrasted with the escapism of techno-soundtracked nights at Funky Town, until both worlds inevitably collide. The screening will be followed by an in-person Q&A with Mullinkosson. After the screening, HOWL Worldwide have curated a line-up of DJs to keep you dancing til late. Doors open at 8.15pm. All tickets will include a free welcome drink and popcorn. To book half-price tickets to all Dazed x MUBI Cinema Club screenings, join Dazed Club. Schedule: 20:15 ‚Äì Doors open 20:30 ‚Äì Film starts 22:00 ‚Äì Q&A hosted by Cici Peng with Ben Mullinkosson 22:30 ‚Äì Q&A ends 22:35 ‚Äì 01:30 ‚Äì Afterparty with DJ sets curated by HOWL: Cosmic Caz and Nanzhen Yang. For more exclusive events, discounts and benefits, Join Dazed Club for just ¬£5/month HERE
Title: Dazed x MUBI Cinema Club: The Last Year of Darkness
Subtitle: Join us for the next Dazed x MUBI Cinema Club screening - UK premiere of the Last Year of Darkness plus director Q&A and afterparty

Description: The Birkbeck Garden History Group is holding a Study Day to explore the diverse ways in which water has been used to enhance the rural and urban environment in both public and private spaces from the mid-20th century to the present day. Programme 10.00 am Registration and coffee 10.25 am Introduction. Chairman: Dominic Cole, Landscape Architect and President of the Gardens Trust 10.30 am Water in modern public landscapes Speaker: Hal Moggridge, Consultant to Colvin & Moggridge, Landscape Architects 11.30 am Short break 11.45 am Hidden treasure: the rediscovery of urban canals since 1945 Speaker: Dr Alan Powers, Architectural Historian and Conservationist 12.45 pm Lunch 2.00 pm Liquid assets: water in the modern private garden Speaker: Dr Katie Campbell, Garden Historian and Writer 3.00 pm Tea 3.30 pm Rewilding Arcadia: 21st-century solutions to manage increasing flood risk along the river Thames Speaker: Jason Debney, Coordinator, Thames Landscape Strategy 4.30 pm Close. Chairman: Dominic Cole For more details about the talks see Study Day (birkbeckgardenhistory.org.uk) Tickets: ¬£60 for BGHG members, ¬£65 for non-members. The ticket includes coffee, sandwich lunch, tea and biscuits. (Own food cannot be consumed on the premises.) Booking closes on the day at 7.30 am on Saturday, 9 March 2024. If you have any questions, please email bghgbookings@gmail.com
Title: BGHG Study Day  -  Water in Modern Designed Landscapes
Subtitle: Learn more about the diverse ways in which designers have made use of water in rural and urban landscapes in the 20th and 21st centuries.

Description: A Stitch To Wear Clothes Swap Join us for a fun and eco-friendly event, the A Stitch To Wear Clothes Swap! Bring your gently used good condition clothes and trade them for something new-to-you. It's a great way to refresh your wardrobe! Date: Saturday, March 9, 2024 Time: 3:00 PM - 6:00PM Location: Sutton Community Dance Saint Nicholas Way, Sutton, SM1 1AX At this event, you'll have the opportunity to swap clothes with fellow fashion enthusiasts, all while reducing waste and promoting sustainable fashion. Whether you have clothes that no longer fit, items you no longer wear, or simply want to try out a new style, this swap is the perfect place to find your next favorite outfit. Not only will you be able to discover unique pieces, but you'll also be contributing to a more sustainable future. By reusing and recycling clothes, we can reduce the impact of fast fashion on the environment. So gather up your unwanted but still fabulous clothes and join us at the A Stitch To Wear Clothes Swap! It's a fantastic opportunity to meet new people, have fun, and find some amazing additions to your wardrobe. Don't miss out on this exciting event! You can bring ~ 10 items of womenswear/menswear including shoes/accessories  5 items children‚Äôs/baby clothing  1 item of homeware (for example candle/cushion/plant) 1 book  1 unused beauty product No underwear/sleepwear/earrings/bobbly clothing/holes/stains/missing buttons/broken zips

Subtitle: We‚Äôre back with our first swap in 2024. Come and swap your good condition clothes/books/homeware/beauty products.

Description: Athens, a great political and cultural power in the 5th and 4th centuries BCE, did not cease to be an important city during the Hellenistic period, despite the decrease in its importance due to new political and cultural centres. But what was its culinary place in the Hellenistic world? Evidence provided from archaeological material, literary sources and food remains reveal that, despite the strength of the conservative Athenian character, there were many changes and innovations, especially in food preparation and cooking techniques. In affluent houses the dining became more elaborate and sophisticated. Even the wine-soaked classical symposium changed; the focus moved from wine to complex banquets where food had a prominent role. The diet of the average, non-elite individual was quite simple whereas the poor ate the cheapest food available for sustenance. A lecture on food tradition and change in the cuisines of Hellenistic Athens will be followed by a dinner of foods that were served at the tables of the affluent and the poor. Participants will try dishes inspired by historical recipes and prepared according to experimental archaeology. You will receive a glimpse into Hellenistic Athenian cuisines and discover the taste of the past. What to expect: Our bar will open one hour before the event starts and remain open for one hour after the event finishes. Itinerary: 17:30 - 18:30 - talk 18:30 - 19:00 - interval with wine serving, olives and cheese 19:00 - 21:00 - dinner Access Access to the building is via a few steps; a stair climber is available, please give us prior notice. A lift provides access to all floors and facilities, except to the third floor. More details can be found on our website. Concessions Members, students, over 65s, Westminster card holders, those with a registered disabled card can book concession tickets. ID will be required at the entrance. Those who require a carer, accompanying carers come free - please contact us to let us know in advance. Event sold out? Please join our waiting list and you will be notified when a ticket becomes available. Please note that tickets are non-refundable.
Title: Ancient Tastes: Tradition and Change in Hellenistic Athens
Subtitle: A unique dinner for food lovers and history enthusiasts combined with a lecture on food tradition and change in Hellenistic Athens.

Description: Come to be entertained and inspired by the Division L International Speech and Evaluation Contests! Contestants have progressed through their club and area contests and are just one contest away from the big District 91 finals. There will be a keynote speech by Robin Sundstrom, Toastmaster and Ted X Speaker, called; 'How Daily Vlogging Makes You A More Confident Speaker'. Robin Sundstr√∂m is a TEDx speaker, Communications Coach, Polyglot and former startup Head of Communications who won the D91 International Speech Contest during his first year as a Toastmaster. This talk explores how anyone can use daily one-minute vlogs to become a better and more confident speaker. By recording yourself speaking daily, you can experience yourself from an outsider's perspective, get valuable feedback on how to improve the way you speak, and learn how to express yourself well when it really matters. We will also have our hall of fame for those who have achieved awards in Division L this Toastmasters year. Not only that, food will be provided and contests are a great opportunity to meet and network with other toastmasters and guests. The international speech contest is a contest of contestants delivering their own original, five to seven minute speeches. For the evaluation contest, contestants will evaluate for two to three minutes about something a speech they have only just seen! This event is hybrid, so you can join online, but it is encouraged to come along in person where at all possible. Toastmasters International is a non-profit organisation that develops people's communication and leadership through individual Toastmasters clubs. Speech contests are a tradition for Toastmasters. To find out more about Toastmasters and find a club visit here: https://www.toastmasters.org
Title: Toastmasters Keynote Speech and Division L Contest
Subtitle: The best speakers from Division L will compete in two fantastic contests, with a fantastic keynote and food provided

Description: Annual International Women's Day Let's Network Special üíú Come join us for an exciting in-person event on Saturday March 9th 2024 at Boathouse Studios. However we want to show you the importance of a strong network whilst catching a vibe ü•≥! We offer our attendees the opportunity to unwind and solidify their new found connections over a free welcome mocktail. Whether you're an entrepreneur, professional, or simply passionate about supporting women's success, this event is for you! With a diverse lineup of speakers, interactive workshops, and engaging panel discussions, you'll gain valuable insights, forge new connections, and leave feeling motivated to take on the world. At our annual International Women's Day Let's Network Fair, you'll have the chance to network with like-minded individuals, share your experiences, and learn from others. Expand your professional circle and build lasting relationships with women from various industries. We believe that when women come together, amazing things happen. Don't miss this incredible opportunity to be part of a supportive community, celebrate each other's achievements, and pave the way for a more inclusive future. We are delighted to announce that we will be hosting a vision board making session at the event for ONLY ¬£3. The focus of this will be putting down on paper the woman you want to become and holding each other accountable. Canvases, pictures, glue, pens and scissors will all be provided. We also have the pleasure of hosting a few business pop ups stalls with the following available: and many more! Free goody bags (WORTH OVER ¬£10) will also be available for the first 20 attendees and FREE organic sanitary products for allüõçÔ∏è LAST LAST, we will be hosting a special IWD quiz where you will have chance to win some of the prizes shown below. Mark your calendars and join us for our 8th Let's Network Fair. Together, let's make a difference and empower women everywhere!
Title: International Women's Day Let's Network Fair
Subtitle: Get ready for an epic networking extravaganza at our 2nd  in-person "International Women's Day Let's Network" event, starting on March 9th!

Description: As we start to emerge from the introspection of ‚ÄòWintering‚Äô, we welcome the first blooms of Spring with full abundance to the pathways of illumination to the lighter warmer days ahead, cleansing and purifying. The fruits of our winter harvest flowering with growth. We clear the way to make space to celebrate equal day and night as we travel towards the Spring Equinox. The retreat will open with the vibration of our intentions, mudra and breath - setting the scene at the start of the journey, before flowing through a movement practice and guided breathwork (pranayama). The journey continues with restoratives into a meditation, leading into a guided yoga nidra, so that we are open and spacious to receive the Power of Crystal Alchemy Sound. Be prepared for a fully immersive transformational experience to nourish and re-connect to your true essence. What to Expect: What to Bring: How to get There: All other props will be at the studio inclusing bolsters, blankets and blocks. There will also be hot chai and snacks during the mingle. Every experience is unique to the individual and will differ with every sound journey. Nurturing a state of deep relaxation, the Alchemy Sound Bowls will meet you exactly where you are, the healing is there if you are open to it. Please note Crystal Sonic Sound Therapy is suitable for many people, however, there are a few conditions that are known contraindications. These include people with epilepsy, fitted pacemakers, or those in the first trimester of pregnancy. Please speak to me first if you have any of these conditions before joining the Sound Journey element part of this day.
Title: Spring Awakening - Half Day Yoga & Crystal Alchemy Sound Retreat
Subtitle: Join Sonal Thakrar for this unmissable half day Yoga & Crystal Alchemy Sound Retreat on Saturday 9th March 2024, 3.00-6.30pm in North London

Description: The Great Game Treasure Hunt St Albans is a unique outdoor treasure hunt. We are rated 5/5 on Google and 4.5/5 on TripAdvisor! The hunt will lead you around the city taking in all its famous landmarks and explaining a little bit of its history along the way. You are given a treasure map, compass and clues to find your way along the route. If you are successful you will reveal where to draw the X on your treasure map to show the location of your treasure - a great pub!  It's one of the best activities to do in St Albans or days out in St Albans you can find! :) It can also be done as a Team Building Exercise or Corporate day out! What to expect: An exciting day out. Exploring famous landmarks and secret back streets. Challenge yourself with puzzles, riddles, codes and orienteering work. If you are successful you will reveal where to draw the X on your treasure map to locate the treasure. The treasure is a great pub serving food and drink. We will book a table at the pub so it's ready and waiting when you arrive. What's in the pack: Clues sheet Treasure map Clipboard Compass Prize envelope (contains a history of the pub and an activity pack) Please bring your own pen to help us save on plastic and our carbon footprint :) How to book: Choose your ticket for 1-2 people, 2-4 people or 5-8 people. You only need one ticket per group of this size. After purchase email¬†info@ggtreasurehunts.com¬†to redeem your ticket. Please include a¬†posting address¬†in your email! Please tell us¬†what time you are starting¬†in your email! It takes around 2-3 hours to complete and we will book a table under your name at the treasure pub. Your pack will be posted to you please allow up to 5 working days for it to arrive. Please note your tickets are flexible and can be chosen on any day that suits you. Pub opening times and kitchen times can be found on our website. U18's¬†are allowed in the pubs during the day but in the evenings some venues might not, please check on our website for these times also. Digital packs If you don't have the time to wait for the physical pack to be posted then ask for the digital pack in your email. This is a PDF of the hunt for you to print out or use on a mobile device, provided is a unique code use this to get the discount for your group. If you get a digital pack then we advise you print the hunt out or bring along a notepad to help with the workings out + a compass or compass app.  :) Good luck!
Title: St Albans Fun Puzzle Treasure Hunt! :)
Subtitle: Go on a super fun puzzle treasure hunt in St Albans, where you can crack codes, solve riddles, and discover hidden gems!

Description: The World Experience Organization is proud to host Odyssey Works' signature workshop now for the first time in London! Early Bird Pricing available until Feb 11, 2023! Dive deep into the complete curriculum of Odyssey Works' intimate and inspiring process on how to create transformative experiences. This class combines the content of our core offerings of empathy & experience design, diagramming, and making meaning workshops, into one intensive that radically changes the way you think about making anything you make. On day 1 we will learn the basics of experience design. On day 2 we will create a powerful experience for one other attendee in the class. The weekend will be intense, perspective-altering, deeply personal, and lots of fun. The workshop is based on the work of Odyssey Works, a performance company that creates weekend-long experiences for one person audiences. This will be held IN PERSON ONLY in London, UK. Light breakfast provided both days. 10am - 5pm both days. Workshop will be led by Odyssey Works Director Ayden LeRoux Find out more about Odyssey Works in Newsweek. The World Experience Organization is the world‚Äôs first and only organization to connect innovators from all experience sectors. We believe that when individual experience thought-leaders share their stories, tools and insights, we can collectively raise the impact of experiences to increase profit, improve wellbeing, and create a better society. Together, we‚Äôll discover what the Experience Economy needs, where it‚Äôs heading ‚Äì and most importantly, what it takes to design and deliver a great experience.Join 500+ experience creators in 39 countries. Learn more about the WXO The Odyssey Works Experience Design Intensive I did in NYC last summer was probably the most compact, relevant, valuable professional development training I've done in my life (and I've done quite a few). -Katie Green
Title: Experience Design Weekend Intensive - London
Subtitle: Learn the basics of experience design and jump into designing a powerful experience. Change your way of working forever!

Description: Cooking up a hot gumbo of New Orleans R&B, Tim Penn brings the sounds of the American Deep South to RJR with his band The Second Line. Step back in time to the Jazz bars of New Orleans for '‚ÄúScintillating piano-based artistry‚Äù from Tim Penn and the Second line, an outfit led by our great friend and veteran pianist. The Second Line draws on the music of Fats Domino, Professor Longhair, Dr John, Allen Toussaint and then stirs it up with a pinch of Ray Charles, Tom Waits and Tim‚Äôs own original compositions, a recipe that has led to a string of sold out shows in London over the last few years. Tim Penn is one of the most ‚Äòin demand‚Äô keyboard players on the roots, songwriter & blues scenes. Going back to the 1970s, he was a member of Twickenham legend Dorris Henderson‚Äôs Eclection and also the Kevin Coyne band alongside Andy Summers (The Police) and Gordon Smith (Described by John Peel as ‚ÄùThe foremost white Blues guitarist in the world ‚Äú ) In Tim‚Äôs own words: ‚ÄúThis is the blues, but with a great big smile on its face‚Äù. Over the last few years, The Second Line has firmly established its reputation as one of the top New Orleans R&B bands in London. If you like the Crescent City‚Äôs rich heritage of Rhythm and Blues mixed in with a nod back to the Jazz greats like Louis Armstrong and Jelly Roll Morton then this is one band you won‚Äôt want to miss. 9pm, Doors from 7pm Iconic speakeasy Ram Jam Records is hidden away behind the award winning Smok‚Äôd pub at The Grey Horse Kingston (and yes we serve all their award winning food and drink). If you would like to book a table (for dining only) please contact the venue at greyhorse@smokd.co.uk and specify you would like to be seated in Ram Jam Records. or put the same request in the notes on your online booking.
Organizer: Ram Jam Records at The Grey Horse Smok'd
Title: The Speakeasy Party: Tim Penn and The Second Line
Subtitle: ‚ÄúScintillating piano-based artistry‚Äù from Tim Penn, New Orleans Blues and Jazz at The Speakeasy Party

Description:
UÔªøPDATE: Warning. Blue Green Algal Bloom.
 
 The water in Black Park lake is temporarily affected by blue green algal blooms. People and domestic animals should avoid contact with the water. Contact can lead to skin rashes, eye irritation, diarrhoea, vomiting, fever and muscular pain.
 
 In the event of contact with the water, please see medical/veterinary advice. 
 
 Thank you for your co-operation.
 Located 100m from the car park, the lake has easy access with several benches and a pathway around it; an accessible fishing bay is located near the Nature Reserve.  Fishing at Black Park Country Park is by Annual Permit or Day Ticket only during car park opening hours.  Both Day Tickets and Annual Permits are available to purchase in advance of your visit, online only. The annual coarse fish closed season applies from the 15th March to the 15th June inclusive.  Please see Fishing Rules and map of fishing areas attached for full details. The annual coarse fish closed season applies 15th March to 15th June inclusive. You must purchase a day ticket or be in possession of an annual pass to fish. You must be in possession of a valid Environment Agency Rod Licence, maximum number of rods 3. Fishing is only permitted during car park opening hours (from 8am to seasonal closing times ‚Äì check Buckinghamshire Country Parks website). No night fishing permitted. Any angler found in breach of Country Parks or Environment Agency rules will be immediately removed from site and reported to the Environment Agency. Local Thames Region Environment Agency byelaws apply. No fish to removed from or released into the lake. All fish must be returned to the water immediately, no keep nets or sacks permitted. No fishing in fenced off nature reserve areas (see map for full details of where you can and cannot fish). Barbless hooks only. Please remove all line and rubbish. Please use sensible quantities of bait, with no pre-baiting permitted. Bait boats should not be used. Children under 16 must be accompanied by an adult. Anglers must move if asked by a representative of the Buckinghamshire Country Parks or a film production. Anglers and associated kit must be located on the lake side of the path (that surrounds the lake). Any broken line or lost rigs must be immediately retrieved. If it is unsafe to retrieve, they must be reported to the Duty Ranger on 07734 734337. Pike fishing season is between October 1st to March 14th. You must be in possession of long forceps and be competent at handling and unhooking pike. A large 36 inch plus net and a large well-padded unhooking mat is required. Strong line to be used (12lb plus) Two treble hooks per trace with semi-barbed hooks permitted. No live baiting. A large 36 inch plus net and a large well-padded unhooking mat is required. Strong line to be used (12lb plus) No fixed leads or unsafe rigs to be used i.e. in case of breakage; all rig components must be able to easily slide over any knots used to join leaders to mainline. Black Park Fishing FAQ's Where can I buy a day ticket / annual permit from? All Fishing Day Tickets and Annual Permits need to be purchased in advance online. Please note that Black Park fishing closes  from 15th March 2023 - 15th June 2024. How much will a Fishing Day Ticket cost me? Day Ticket:		Adult  ¬£7*   /   Concession  ¬£5.50*  / Child (Under 12) ¬£1* *Please note that there is a small online booking fee added at checkout. Does the adult need to buy Day Ticket as well as child if only the child is fishing? No.  If only the child is fishing, then only a child ticket needs to be bought.  However if you have multiple rods then both adult and child will need a ticket. Can I fish anytime of the year? Black Park continues to operate a closed season 15 March-15 June inclusive. Can I night fish? No.  Fishing is only permitted in Black Park Lake during car park opening times (8am-seasonal closing times daily). Are there any rules I need to abide by when I fish? Yes, fishing rules are attached on email to every Day Ticket purchased and in the information above. Please make yourself familiar with these. Where can I fish? The map above shows you where you can / can‚Äôt fish on Black Park Lake.  Please make yourself familiar with this. Who do I contact if I would like to discuss Black Park Fishing further? Buckinghamshire Country Parks Team 01753 511060 / countryparks@buckinghamshire.gov.uk
Title: Fishing DAY TICKET - Black Park (2023/2024)
Subtitle: Black Park Lake is a beautiful lake in the heart of South Buckinghamshire with fantastic fishing opportunities and iconic scenery.

Description: Our first visit of the year to The Seven Sisters Take part in one of our most popular adventures, the Seven Sisters, including Cuckmere Haven, The Birling Gap, and Beachy Head. This adventure offers some of the most spectacular coastline the British Isles has to offer! Trek/Fit Hike: Challenge Category Distance: About 27km Elevation Gain: 800 meters Duration: Approximately 7 hours Who's It For?This hike is perfect for those who love a good day of walking while taking in the scenery! üèûÔ∏è It's suitable for anyone 18+ who's physically fit and ready to complete the hike unaided. Safety First: What to Wear & Bring - Walking shoes/boots with good grip (not gym/road running trainers) üëü - Synthetic-based gym shorts, leggings, or non-cotton jogging bottoms (no jeans or chinos) ü©≥ - Waterproofs to stay dry ‚òî - Dress in layers for comfort üß• - Don't forget sunscreen for protection! üß¥ Trains to Book: 09:24 Return LDN Victoria to Eastbourne, and a 10:30 Single from Lewes to Seaford Meet Up Point: 09:00 LDN Victoria, outside Boots, inside the Station. Cost: ¬£15.00 per person excluding Eventbrite's booking fee and your train tickets/travel to the hike's starting point. Regrettably no refunds, but we're happy to transfer your ticket to another hike of the same price as long as you notify us before 18:00 on 8th March. Terms and conditions apply. Visit www.trekfit.co.uk/transfers for full details. Book by: The night before (8th March) on Eventbrite. It helps us plan and keep you in the loop. Safety & Updates: Safety is our priority! In case of train strikes or extreme weather, we'll reschedule and keep you posted on Eventbrite. Have Questions? Need Info? Send an email to support@trekfit.co.uk. We're here to make this hike an amazing experience for you!
Title: Trek/Fit Challenge Hikes: The Seven Sisters
Subtitle: Take part in the most famous hike in the South Downs - the Seven Sisters, from Seaford to Eastbourne!

Whether you're into art or spirituality or just curious about what a supportive connection between women is like, here you find a place to recharge! I can't wait to share this circle with you!

Description: ____________________________________________________________________ Saturday 9th March 2pm - 4pm Lunchtime session 10 attendees per session ____________________________________________________________________  This low-stakes making workshop utilises Mudlarked remnants and lo-fi supplementary materials to explore the making of charms, talismans and objects of safety. As opposed to historical artefacts, the materials provided are intended to act as emotionally charged, mnemonic devices that function as catalysts for meaningful conversation between participants. Mackenzie Willis (b. 1994) is a Canadian Maker & self-identified MAD woman who uses found objects and traditional craft practices to create reflexive objects and textiles. Willis‚Äôs research by art practice concerns Making as a Healing practice by Auto-Ethnography.Having been first diagnosed with Childhood Panic Disorder at the age of six, Willis has reflected upon the physical shapes that her life-long chronic-illness have materialized. Upon first arrival to London, UK in August 2021, Willis utilised Mudlarking as a means of self-therapy due to the lack of access to readily available health-care. Willis has sought comfort by collecting artefacts along the Thames and thereafter, through actions of cleaning, processing and effecting new composite objects by means of rigorous self-reflection. Through the externalization of her illness and the mnemonic quality of the materials, Willis exteriorizes fragility and beared witness in the quality of the found materials. Willis currently works as the Workshop Technician in Makerversity, located under Somerset House. Moreover, Willis has worked extensively in Design Research, most recently with OCADU as a Graduate Research Assistant for OCADU in Toronto, Canada, as well as a Design by Repair Researcher with the Restart Project in London, UK. ____________________________________________________________________ Ticket Prices Free  (Low income/Concessions) ¬£5 (donation ticket for Mackenzie's time) ____________________________________________________________________ On the day of the event guests will be picked from the New Wing reception of Somerset House. This is based on Lancaster Place, following on from Waterloo Bridge. If lost please do call 02037017499 Address: Makerversity, New Wing, Somerset House, London, WC2R 1LA ____________________________________________________________________ Makerversity is a pioneering community of over 300 world-leading entrepreneurs, creators and innovators. Member companies work at the intersection of design, engineering and digital practice, developing ground-breaking solutions for the world‚Äôs biggest societal challenges, including climate change, health and inequality. Makerversity supports these early-stage teams with specialist prototyping facilities, affordable workspace, and a business support platform. As part of our ongoing commitment to diversity and inclusion, Makerversity is proud to support International Women's Day 2024 by hosting a series of events that highlight the remarkable contributions of female founders, designers, artists, and engineers. Join us in celebrating the achievements of these inspiring individuals and fostering a culture of creativity and innovation that embraces all perspectives. Makerversity is dedicated to providing a platform for diverse voices, and these events exemplify our dedication to shaping a more inclusive future for all - check out our other events happening on and around 8th March.
Title: Making as Mudlarks
Subtitle: This making workshop utilises Mudlarked remnants and lo-fi supplementary materials to explore the making of charms and talismans

Description: Secure Parking at Turing House School for events at Twickenham Rugby Stadium. How to find us: Turing House School, Hospital Bridge Road, TW2 6LH. Approx 1 mile from the stadium. We're about a 20-minute walk from the stadium or a 10-min bus ride on the 481. You can walk via Whitton High Street which has coffee shops, pubs, toilets and. Our school is ideally situated 2-min drive from the A316 giving an easy route in, and back out of the area. Gates open 4 hours before the match Kick Off time and then are closed permanently 2 hours after the match ends. There is no overnight parking. If you don‚Äôt collect your car before lock-up time there will be an extra cost. Please purchase a Minibus ticket for long-wheelbase vehicles.  When you book you should receive an immediate confirmation. Please bring this when you come to park- either as a printed copy or on your phone. Some car spaces may be available on the day for ¬£20 at the gate (subject to availability), we will always recommend pre-booking your space for peace of mind. If your match or concert is cancelled we will process a full refund. All monies raised after the deduction of expenses are donated to Turing House School to fund equipment, transport and activities for the benefit of the children. Please note, the organisers and parking marshals are parent volunteers. All vehicles parking do so at the owner's own risk, we cannot be held responsible for any theft or vehicle damage when parked on our grounds If you are late for pick-up and the car park is locked please contact thf@turinghouseschool.org.uk. Hosted in the cozy setting of Kirtbir‚Äôs home, you will be warmly welcomed for an evening of authentic family recipes, and unlimited masala chai to wash it all down. "Didi" translates to 'older sister' in Punjabi, and with Didi Supper, you'll feel like one of the family. Punjabi food is so much more than tikka masala ‚Äì you‚Äôll be treated to a feast of vegetarian and non-vegetarian delicacies from the state. With so many vibrant flavours to sample, there will be something for everyone, so come hungry! "It brings me so much joy to be able to share my culture, food and community through a supper club - it's the perfect setting to learn more about the food we are eating, where it comes from, and who has influenced it because Punjabi food isn't just 'curry'. We'll swap stories of our families, our communities, and our lives and hopefully make new friends along the way. Description: The inaugural Envirohealth Forum 2024 Conference will be held on 9th March in London. This event will bring together leading global experts in health effects from water-damaged environments. Whilst there is no disagreement on whether mould impacts on human health, this conference will explore the ways in which this happens, where there is consensus, and where there are still key questions that need to be addressed, and what other factors may need to be considered to be able to answer the question does mould really matter? We will be focusing on a few key areas to answer these questions:Genetics- The genetics of risk from exposure will be explored, to help us to consider whether mould matters for everyone, or just those with a specific genetic risk? Triggers- The Conference will also be introducing new elements found in water-damaged environments that may also be affecting human health, such as actinomycetes, endotoxins and beta glucans, This will help us to re-frame the question of does mould really matter, when we place mould and mycotoxins in the wider context of these other factors. We will also be considering in this section the effects of exposure and how this can create a different presentation for individuals. Environmental Factors- From an environmental perspective we will be considering what other factors contribute to sick building syndrome and mediate an environment to increase risk. Action Plans- To round off the day we will be considering options for practitioners to utilise in clinical practice
Title: CIRS-EU: Envirohealth Forum 2024 "Does Mould Really Matter?" Conference
Subtitle: The inaugural Envirohealth Forum 2024 Conference. The inaugural Envirohealth Forum 24 This event will bring together leading global experts

Description: Hans & Gretel - The Untold Tale Theatre Experience Join us for an enchanting and immersive theatre experience like no other! Step into the magical world of Hans & Gretel as we unveil the untold tale of their extraordinary adventure. Get ready to be captivated by a mesmerising performance that will transport you to a land of wonder and mystery. Location: Hans & Gretel Camden - Unit 91 - Stables Market, Chalk Farm Road, NW1 8AH Prepare to be dazzled by a breathtaking set, stunning costumes, and a performance that will bring this timeless story to life. Immerse yourself in the whimsical atmosphere, as you follow the breadcrumbs and discover the secrets hidden within the enchanted cottage... Whether you're a fan of fairy tales or simply seeking an unforgettable experience, this event promises to leave you spellbound. Don't miss out on this extraordinary journey into the world of Hans and Gretel! What does this event include? An unforgettable Storytelling Theatrical Experience from our professional performers. Step into our cozy witches' cottage and prepare for a spellbinding performance that will keep you on the edge of your seat. But that's not all ‚Äì as a special treat, each guest will receive a gift bag filled with hand selected Hans & Gretel treats and a signature dessert after the show. Dates Selected dates throughout February and March 2024. Times Each performance is approximately 20 minutes long. Sessions take place at selected times throughout the day *Please ensure you arrive no more than 10 minutes before your booking to avoid congestion and overcrowding, this will ensure the safety of our customers and staff. Please note session times are staggered, and therefore your experience may not start at your booking time. *See the booking page for specific times How much does it cost? ¬£20.00 per person. The maximum amount of people per booking is 6, this must include one adult. Bookings must be made and paid for in advance. Am I allowed to bring more people than I booked for? No additional people will be allowed into the performance apart from those in posession of a purchased ticket. Anyone attending on the day without a ticket will not be permitted entry. What steps are you taking to ensure a safe environment? At Hans & Gretel, we are proud to have created an environment that is enjoyable, fun, and safe. Our customers and colleagues safety are our top priority and as such, our teams have worked hard to ensure that we continue to help you and your family create magical memories, safely. To ensure safety, we have identified and assessed potential risks and implemented control measures. There is a maximum of 6 people per performance and each session will be dedicated to this group number to ensure a personal experience. What age is it suitable for? The Untold Tale at Hans & Gretel Camden is most suitable for those aged 6 and above Are parents and guardians allowed to watch? Parents and guardians are invited to enjoy the performance ONLY if a booking has been made which includes them in the group. Without prior booking online, any additional people will not be allowed into the performance room. There must be one adult present for each group booked. Menu No food or drink is allowed during the performance, however each guest will receive a Hans & Gretel gift bag and signature dessert of their choosing after the show. Food and drink is available to purchase in-store before and after the performance. Terms & Conditions Please read our Terms and Conditions before booking your ticket(s). By purchasing ticket(s) for The Untold Story at Hans & Gretel you & your child(s) are agreeing to comply with our Terms and Conditions. All children must be accompanied by at least one adult and must remain under that adult‚Äôs supervision at all times. *The welfare and safety of all children therefore remains the full responsibility of the parent/guardian attending and not of Hans & Gretel staff. *Children attending together in the same group can be supervised by one adult. In these circumstances there must be one adult per booking. TICKETS The performances at Hans & Gretel Camden is tailored for children aged 6 and above. Bookings must be made by someone over 18. Every group booking must include at least one adult. Please note any person of any age who is not booked to attend the performance will not be allowed entry to the room. One ticket grants entry for one person into the performance. Any additional guests that wish to be included in the booking must have purchased an extra ticket (applicable for all ages). There is a maximum number of 6 people per booking. REFUNDS Due to popular demand, we cannot offer any refunds for no-shows or cancellations made less than 48 hours in advance of your booking. MY BOOKING Once you have completed your booking you will receive a confirmation email, including your booking reference number. You must present a copy of this confirmation on the day you permit your entry into the performance. ENTRY TO THE PERFORMANCE AT HANS & GRETEL Please arrive no earlier than 10 minutes before your session to avoid congestion and overcrowding. Performances are staggered throughout the day, therefore your visit may not start exactly at the time of your booking. MEETING POINT Children attending the performance at Hans & Gretel London will be greeted by a Hans & Gretel cast memeber in the store in Camden Market. Late entry will result in a loss of the booking, and we will be unable to rearrange your ticket. Hans & Gretel Camden can get particularly busy. We advise customers to take this into account when planning your visit. BEHAVIOUR We reserve the right to ask guests to leave if we believe their behaviour is adversely affecting the pleasure of our other guests. SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS It is the parent or guardian's responsibility to inform us at the time of booking of any special educational needs or disabilities and we will ensure they are accommodated for. PHOTOGRAPHY You are welcome to bring your own camera to take photos of your special memories. Please note that any photos can only be for personal use and not commercial use. No filming or photography is allowed during the performance. RUNNING ORDER We reserve the right to change the order of events of any event at Hans & Gretel. Whilst we will always provide a fun range of creative and imaginative activities for children, we reserve the right to vary the range of activities, according to unforeseen circumstances. We provide a fun generic gift bag that is suitable for all ages. The contents of the gift bag can be altered by Hans & Gretel at any time due to unforeseen circumstances. No gifts can be exchanged for alternatives or cash voucher. LIABILITY Hans & Gretel UK Ltd will not be liable for any injuries, loss of personal possessions, other losses or damage of any kind. This is due to the fact that all children are under the supervision of parents/ guardians throughout the visit. We will not be liable or responsible for cancellation due to an event outside our control e.g., severe weather conditions, fire, flood, terrorist attack, and unexpected black out, electricity failure. If this happens, we will attempt to provide an alternative visiting time for you, but this cannot be guaranteed. These terms and conditions shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of England and Wales and are subject to the jurisdiction of English courts.
Title: Hans & Gretel Theatre Experience - Saturday 9th March
Subtitle: Join us for a captivating theatre experience as we unravel the untold tale of Hans & Gretel, filled with enchantment and wonder!

Description: A bojagi or pojagi is a traditional Korean wrapping cloth. Bojagi are typically square and can be made from a variety of materials, though silk or ramie are common. Embroidered bojagi are known as subo, while patchwork or scrap bojagi are known as jogakbo. (Wiki) In this workshop you will learn how to make a simple version 'bojagi' or 'jogak' style wall patchwork hanging or curtain reusing linen offcuts and sheer samples salvaged from the interior design industry for reuse. You will choose your own colourway of fabrics and learn how to do the simple flat seam that is required to make these beautiful sheer wall hangings. This is an all-day event limited to just 5 participants. This full-day workshop is held at Yodomo's new Textile Reuse Hub in Hackney Wick. Led by Yodomo's founder Sophie Rochester, you will learn to create a simple wall hanging or curtain. All materials and sewing machines are provided. Participants may also bring their own materials if they want to incorporate these into their works. About Yodomo Yodomo is a social venture on a mission to increase wellbeing and promote the understanding of the reuse of materials by facilitating wider participation in making and crafts. We believe that making is good for you and good for the planet. The word 'Yodomo' is short for 'You Do More'. We encourage participation in crafts and making by bringing the expertise of independent artists and makers directly to you. Our makers teach either online, through kits or at live events. About Yodomo Circular Hubs Yodomo runs Yodomo Circular Hubs which connects businesses, makers and communities, finding innovative solutions to creatively reuse pre-consumer waste and surplus materials. Premised on the logic of the circular economy, we seek to provide practical solutions to reusing waste while benefiting the creative community and local businesses of Hackney. Sign up to become a member here. About the Textile Reuse Hub The workshop will take place at the new Textile Reuse Hub, a demonstrator project for Hackney Wick & Fish Island Community Development Trust's #ReRoute project in a new space provided by The Trampery HWFI. About the venue and accessibility at the Textile Reuse Hub W e are on the ground floor with good access from the pavement. Toilets and baby changing There is an accessible toilet in the Textile Reuse Hub
Title: Learn to sew a 'bojagi' style patchwork wall hanging reusing sheer samples
Subtitle: Learn to sew a 'bojagi' style patchwork to create a curtain or wall hanging reusing linen and sheer samples at the Yodomo Textile Reuse Hub
